newsitem.title: USA: Moody's cuts Miami GO to Ba1, sees state takeover.
newsitem.headline: Moody's cuts Miami GO to Ba1, sees state takeover.

text.p: Moody's Investors Service cut Miami's general obligation bond rating to Ba1 from Baa on Monday, and said it had been advised by Florida officials that a state takeover of the city was "imminent."
"We were told by the state officials that that's imminent, either late today or early tomorrow," Moody's vice president John Incorvaia said.
"We're not doing anything tonight," Gov Lawton Chiles spokeswoman Karen Pankowski said. "Call us tomorrow."
The rating cut means the city's GO bonds below investment grade and indicates they "are judged to have speculative elements."

Incorvaia cited Miami Mayor Joe Carollo's meeting with Gov Chiles last week as a factor in the downgrade. Carollo told the governor the city had a financial crisis and said he would welcome the appointment of an emergency board to run the city.

"Having gone to the governor is indicative of the severity of the budget crisis, coupled with the political resistance to enact relatively moderate revenue enhancement proposals," Incorvaia said. "All this makes it appear increasingly questionable that the city will be able to restore fiscal balance without some outside intervention."
Miami has a $68 million deficit in its $275 million budget for the year that began Oct 1.
The govenor has previously criticized the city commission for failing to quickly enact fee hikes that could help balance the budget.
